section.name: TimestampSelector
section.p: The TimestampSelector task takes either a nested path element, or a path reference, and sets either a named property, or a path instance to absolute pathnames of the files with either the N latest or earliest modification dates (based on the age attribute)

tr.td: The property to set with the most recently modified file. Mutually exclusive with the outputsetid attribute.
Yes, if outputsetid is not specified.
The id of a path instance which will contain the resulting list of files. This id should not already exist. Mutually exclusive with the property attribute
Yes, if property is note specified.
The number of files to find. If more than 1, than the files in the output appear in the order indicated by the age attribute.
The age of the files to retrieve, either eldest or youngest. Defaults to youngest.
The path separator to separate paths with when using the property attribute in conjunction with the count attribute
Id of the path to find the most recently modified file in.
No, if a path subelement is specified.

subsection.name: Parameters specified as nested elements
subsection.p: Path is used to select sets of files or directories in which to find the most recently modified file

subsection.name: Example
subsection.source:
<path id="mypath"> <fileset dir="${log.dir}"> <include name="update*.log"/> </fileset> <path> <timestampselector property="most.recent.logs" pathref="mypath" count="3" pathsep=";"/>
<echo message="${most.recent.logs}"/>

<timestampselector property="most.recent.logs" count="3" pathsep=";" > <path> <fileset dir="${log.dir}"> <include name="update*.log"/> </fileset> <path> </timestampselector>
<echo message="${most.recent.logs}"/>

<timestampselector outputsetref="most.recent.logs" pathref="mypath" count="3"> <path> <fileset dir="${log.dir}"> <include name="update*.log"/> </fileset> <path> </timestampselector>
<copy todir="somedir"> <path refid="most.recent.logs"/> </copy>
